subject: More Hugo Thoughts
event: Continuing the conversation I began in my Not A Post of November 2... Last time I talked about some possible nominees for Dramatic Presentation, Long Form. This time I want to focus on Dramatic Presentation, Short Form. In other words, best television episode. (No, not officially, but that's what it usually comes down to, and let's ignore the silliness of nominating an Easter Egg or an acceptance speech from the previous year's Hugos). I was no fan of the efforts of Puppies to game the Hugo Awards last year. I don't think I have been shy in my opinions on that subject. But I will give the Puppies this much -- their efforts did break the decade-long hold that Dr. Who fandom had on the nominations in this category. I have no problem with episodes of DR. WHO being nominated, and indeed winning, mind you... and the Doctor has won plenty of times in this category over the past decade... but when four of the six finalists are from the same category, that strikes me as way unbalanced and, well, greedy. The Doctor's fans love their show, I know, but there is a LOT of great SF and fantasy on the tube right now. Nominate DR. WHO, by all means... but leave some room for someone else, please. (And yes, I would feel the same way if it was four episodes of GAME OF THRONES being nominated every year, rather than four episodes of DR. WHO). Last year, for the first time in recent memory, we actually had five different series represented on the final ballot. In addition to GAME OF THRONES and DR. WHO, the two shows that had dominated the previous three years, we also had ORPHAN BLACK (the eventual winner), plus episodes of THE FLASH and GRIMM. The Puppies had something to do with that, I can't deny that. Nonetheless, I do think it was a healthy development. I hope we have five different series represented this year as well... though maybe not the same five. There's a lot to choose from, actually. Yes, DR. WHO. No way to keep the Doctor off the ballot. Yes, GAME OF THRONES. I am only human, so I do hope we contend again... I'd favor "Hardhome" myself, but "Mother's Mercy," with Cersei's walk of shame, could be a strong choice as well. ORPHAN BLACK is the defending champion, and should get another nod as well. THE FLASH? Maybe. But there's also ARROW and GOTHAM and AGENTS OF SHIELD for the comic book fans out there (I count myself as one of those), and now SUPERGIRL as well. GRIMM was nominated last year, and is still going strong. And there's ONCE UPON A TIME as well. That one has never gotten a nod. However, looking beyond previous nominees, there are lots of shows out there that might be due for a bit of Hugo love. Start with the zombie triad: the very grim WALKING DEAD, the very tongue-in-cheek Z NATION, plus I, ZOMBIE. The undead are well represented. And for horror fans, there's also AMERICAN HORROR STORY. A perennial Emmy contender, yet it never seems to get any notice at Hugo time. I love scary stories myself, count myself a fan of Lovecraft and Poe and Stephen King, so I've sampled and enjoyed most of these shows. The one I like better than any of them, though? PENNY DREADFUL. That's the one I'll be including on my own Hugo ballot. I am tempted to mention THE LAST KINGDOM as well... but as much as I love it, it really isn't eligible. A terrific show, one you should all be watching, but it's straight historical fiction, with no fantasy elements. However, I will mention another show that might otherwise be overlooked: OUTLANDER. Yes, it is a historical. Yes, it is a romance. But it is also a science fiction show. TIME TRAVEL, remember? Plus, it's just flat out terrific. Great production values, first rate writing and directing, and some amazing acting... all three of the leads gave performances worthy of Emmy nods this past year, though the Academy overlooked them. I hope that fandom doesn't make the same mistake. Let's spread the love. Lots of people are doing good work in television right now, and deserve some recognition. Five nominations, five different series, that's my hope. When the time comes to make your nominations, look beyond the usual suspects.

comments.article: I really enjoy American Horror Story and Outlander, so fingers crossed... Unfortunately the new seasons of AHS have split the fandom quite a bit
Don't forget Daredevil in the comic book category.  Netflix did a great job with the first season.
comments.subject: Daredevil

comments.article: Haven't seen DAREDEVIL myself, but I do hear it was good.
comments.subject: Re: Daredevil

comments.article:
Penny Dreadful is a lot of fun. I was not entirely sure what to expect at first, as I have watched other terrible mish-mashes of stories centering around characters from different books and authors showing up. But they are not heavy handed about it and Eva Green is a fantastic actress. Seeing Timothy Dalton at 72 years old running around doing an action series is also great fun.

Outlander has phenomenal production values, a great story, and really fleshed out characters. Ron Moore hit this one out of the park with the production altogether.
comments.subject: Gotta agree

comments.article: Eva Green is becoming one of my favorite actors.  I love Penny Dreadful.  It's basically doing League of Extraordinary Gentlemen (African Explorer, Scientist, etc...) but in a much better version than that horrendous movie.
comments.subject: Re: Gotta agree

comments.article:
My Raiders finally beat your Jets! Yay for all those times you kicked us when we were down and beaten by your mean, green, fighting machine!

And, now, of course, you're ahead of us in the wild card race.

*sigh
comments.subject: I didn't get a chance to say...

comments.article: Hey George, what do you think about the World Fantasy award trophy not being modelled after H.P. Lovecraft anymore?
comments.subject: H.P. Lovecraft

comments.article: I think THE LEFTOVERS should qualify. Though it is about a perceived religious event, they've also introduced these scientific theories about whatever happened to the 2%. I really feel like Lindelof has been influenced by his love for GAME OF THRONES (and your books, since he was a fan long before ASOIAF) since season 2 is thick with these notions of perception determining reality.
comments.subject: How about...

comments.upictitle: The Captain Of My Ship, The Master Of My Soul: Spider.
comments.article:
And honestly as big a fan as I am of Doctor Who, I'm not convinced it's deserved to be nominated for several years now. It would truly be nice to see some new names up there.

Da Vinci's Demons deserves recognition. (A far better Doctor Who show than Doctor Who of late.)

And yes, season 2 of Penny Dreadful was absolutely delightful.

Outlander was amazing and those last two episodes put it in my list for most compelling television to watch. I haven't been affected by a show like that in a long time but those scenes in the dungeon just pull you in and wont let you look away even though all you want is for it to end.

Any show that can connect on such an emotional level with its audience shows masterful work by the cast and crew from the actors, producers, and director to the set designers and makeup artists and it deserves all the recognition that it gets.
comments.subject: agreed

comments.article:
The Venture Brothers has a special eligible ("All This and Gargantua-2", aired January 2015). Despite being one of the most brilliantly-written series on television, and unquestionably SFF, The Venture Brothers has never even been nominated for a Hugo.

Individual episodes of Welcome to Night Vale (season 2) are also eligible, as let's not forget that this category is not limited to television shows.
Jessica Jones looks like it's going to be good, too, and could be worth a nod. Not to mention Daredevil - you seem to be favouring DC!

Personally, I am really hoping the dominance of TV is broken and Welcome to Night Vale gets a nomination. It is a spectacular podcast, and my biggest problem is trying to decide which episode is strongest. Their "Investigators" live show I attended is what I want to nominate, but unless a recording is released, I certainly don't see a live show doing very well. ("Sorry you missed it, but trust me, you should totally vote for it!") Besides it would probably be Long Form instead, anyway. ;)

Also, as yet another plug, I'm still encouraging any and everyone to participate in the Hugo Recommendation Season (https://hugorecommend.wordpress.com/). We will be posting about Best Fan Writer this week and Best Professional Artist next week! I'm hoping people will be interested in talking about some of the quieter categories other than Best Novel, Best Dramatic Presentation (LF & SF), etc. that normally dominate the attention. We would love to hear George's and anyone else's opinions on all of these categories as well!
comments.subject: Welcome to Night Vale

comments.article: i'd like my current favourites "The Librarians", "Continuum", "Haven" & "Sleepy Hollow"to get a nod.
Partial to Agent Carter and Sense8, as far as this year's TV offerings.

Yes, Sense8 - definitely! As an individual episode, I'm partial to "What is Human?" as the most striking individual episode - plus it stands well on it's own. the final two episodes - which are also strong - are really strongest as part of the whole story. In fact, I plan on nominating the entire season for Long Form as well since it works very well as single long story much more than many other series.

(Still gotta finish watching Agent Carter - geez, I'm behind.)
Countdown until the two Hugo camps start intermarrying.
comments.subject: Georhaerys the Conciliator!

comments.article:
Second the nomination suggestion for Penny Dreadful. Second season even better than first - and Eva Green. Nuff Said. (Despite love from Emmy not my favorite season of Horror Story - remember Hugo is a year behind).

Would like to nominate Bastard Executioner but like Last Kingdom not enough fantasy to qualify (though a bit more than Kingdom). Has some over the top moments (as does GOT at times - call it cable shock) but good story, costumes and great female lead (plus Welsh rebels).

Orphan Black, Arrow, Flash - lots of Good Stuff (and Who too). Hardhomme for sure. Outlander already has my wife's vote.

Odd that most of these shows have already passed through Emmy's embrace (Mother not Hardhomme got nomination). Hugos are very late in the award season. Something about being hung up on Labor Day...but I digress.

Embarresment of riches for fantasy/SiFi/historical fiction.

TomT
comments.subject: Short From

comments.article:
If the pilot episode was any indication, the Man in the High Castle looks like it will be pretty great, too. They could do (and have done) a lot with that alternate history PKD created, assuming alternate history is still considered eligible. And it's probably too silly to get a nod, but Ash vs Evil Dead is pretty hilarious, speaking of the undead.

Agents of Shield is having a really good season this year. I particularly loved "4,722 Hours."

Doctor Who is great -- and hey, Maisie Williams is in it this season! So many options -- you're right, share the love.
comments.subject: Even more options...

comments.article:
I think "4,722 Hours" would get an nomination (I found the episode a bit predictable, but the execution was very good).
Im a fan of Dark matter, but Im afraid, not enough people watched it and it got much stronger at the end of the season. Also, like with Daredevil, its hard to pin an individiual episode, because its the story arc thats compelling.
comments.subject: Re: Even more options...

comments.article:
I was watching Hardhome with my friends, and, while I usually would've gone for the outstanding finale with Mother's Mercy, I pretty happy you in particular single out Hardhome.

What really makes this episode are the quiet moments between characters we know, and to some extent understand. It's a pretty quiet, almost gentle episode.

But then the sheer spectacle, rife with emotional weight, in a tense and bareknuckle struggle, in the most intricate and massive battle sequence in the history of television (it gives Blackwater and Watchers on the Wall a run for their money)... yeah man. Hardhome is one great hour of entertainment.

I gotta say, it really does speak volumes for the quality of the material, that something so consistently excellent can provide that kind of action in a totally non-cheap or facile way.

Those last 3 episodes of the season are really exceptional, all though, so it's stiff competition.

Thanks in large part to your work, as well as the resurgence in comic books and the mystical/supernatural, today there is just so much quality viewing in the fantasy/sci-fi space. I've always hoped to see some of your 1000 Worlds stories adapted for the screen as well. Though of course, after the son and grandson of Kong see the light of day. How is that progressing? Oh and congratulations on the honors from Northwestern.
comments.subject: Television

comments.article: What about the british show Humans?
comments.subject: Humans

comments.article: HUMANS was good as well.  Thanks for the reminder.
comments.subject: Re: Humans

comments.article:
I will, in all seriousness, be nominating "Tiny Hamster Is A Giant Monster" because it's fantastic homage to classic monster films it made me laugh more than any tv show I've seen this year, the technical skills used to pull this off are actually really impressive, and, y'know, there's a hamster.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AQte2nz80Is
Yes.  That deserves a Hugo of some sort.  Yes.
comments.subject: Clicked the link

comments.article: I love that you mentioned Outlander and Penny Dreadful. Two great shows that are severely underrated. I'd throw one more in there, The Leftovers. It was great in season 1 and season 2 has been even better. An emotional journey every week.

I'm glad you mentioned Outlander, I think it's wonderful and have been reading the series because of the show. I'm ALL about time Travel (and Ghosts!). I still wish NBC had not canceled Journey Man back in 2008 (or was it 2007?).
I know this seems a bit farfetched, but, I wish they'd include Deadbeat (from Hulu). It's a ghost themed story, so isn't that "fantasy"? it's hilarious!
I love Penny Dreadful, Orphan Black and of course Dr Who, but The Walking Dead kinda rules!
I'm STOKED for The Expanse release!!!!
Oh! What about Defiance? I guess Falling Skies is considered lame by the authorities?
;)

Just wanted to put in my 2 cents here. Thanks George.
BTW I just read The Hero and Men of Greywater Station, very cool stuff!!

Don't forget DAREDEVIL in the superhero category! First half was stronger than the second half, admittedly, but there's a lot of promise in the cast... and of course the source material, some great storylines they can mine.

THE LEFTOVERS has been pretty exceptional this season, as well. The last couple of episodes have been real knock-outs.
I loved Vincent Donofrio in Daredevil.

THE STRAIN and VIKINGS.

These are two more great shows filmed/produced in Canada that deserve consideration. THE STRAIN is US produced, shot in Canada; Vikings is Canadian produced, shot in Ireland. KILLJOYS - from the company behind ORPHAN BLACK - could also be a contender in the future (they only really laid the groundwork by the end of seasons 1), not to mention SUPERNATURAL which a lot of people seem to love (11 seasons!? Sheesh.)

With VIKINGS, THE STRAIN, ORPHAN BLACK, THE FLASH, ARROW, IZOMBIE, ONCE UPON A TIME, SUPERNATURAL, possibly KILLJOYS and a few others, Canadian produced and/or Canadian filmed speculative fiction series have certainly staked out some good ground in the last several years. Gone are the days of the occasion X-FILES or BATTLESTAR with mostly second rate action stuff being shot here in the Great White North. There's some really quality stuff being made in - and in some cases actually originating from - Canada these days.

One final note on VIKINGS: In its first two seasons there were some fantastical allusions in the show, but with introduction of Kevin Durand's character and story arc this year - ironically, a Canadian actor who is also a series regular on the THE STRAIN - VIKINGS now, unquestionably, qualifies as fantasy.

Similarly, THE BASTARD EXECUTIONER - from SONS OF ANARCHY creator Kurt Sutter - also has sufficient mystical elements to qualify, I'd say. THE LAST KINGDOM really does seem to be the bastard step-child when it comes to Medieval series left out of Hugo consideration.
comments.subject: Two more shows that should be clear contenders for Hugos nominations...

comments.article:
Wish I had remembered to mention the Strain. Great show and a better take on fighting "minion/zombie" plague then most Zombie shows (artillery and airpower would be the solution to most zombie hordes).

Vikings while historical fantasy (and a good show) probably is still to grounded in real events to qualify - we have a slew of fantasy/SiFi to choose from arleady.

TomT
comments.subject: Re: Two more shows that should be clear contenders for Hugos nominations...

comments.article:
If you're talking about Superheroes tv series you should not have left out Powers. The comic is solidly written with a nice twisty background as starting point and i've heard some very positive voices towards the screen adaption, although i haven't gotten to watch it myself yet. And Heroes is most likely not far behind in elegibility either.

Not a fan of Zombies though. It has gotten a bit exhausting how much those stories get hyped in the last few years. Even "Tabletop" got close to a point where it was unwatchable due to the many zombie themed games they played, and there are a lot more books, movies and tv series than boardgames with that sujet... so at least hope the zombie-fans will only choose ONE of the triad and be done with it... there are after all only five spots on the ballots to contend for

Oh and after the interview with Bruce Campbell and Lucy Lawless at Colberts Late Show on ehh Tuesday? Ash vs Evil Dead seems also to be headed to watchable glory. Zombies / Undead again... but adorable actors... *sigh* The world is clearly unfair. :D
